content.html:
Two months ago I started implementing IndieWeb principles on my website. I use started because it has been a long process of tinkering with different tools and learning to use technologies I never expected to be using.

Naturally, the progress has been slow as I‚Äôm often running into problems beyond my skillset. However, by reaching out to other community members I‚Äôve been able to slowly setup things kind of the way I want. Because it‚Äôs true that on the IndieWeb everyone assumes you‚Äôre a developer, but most people are nice enough to open source their code and even go the extra mile helping with one‚Äôs particular use cases.

This website‚Äôs original goal was for me to have an online presence that was fully controlled by me, but thanks to the IndieWeb it‚Äôs turning into my single Internet channel. And how can it not progress in that direction when there‚Äôs many inspiring websites on the IndieWebring alone?

What started as moving my content back to Jekyll from Tumblr, resulted in personal website that implemented microformats, used a Heroku-hosted micropub endpoint and relied on Quill to post updates. Right now everything I need to post or read online is hosted on my personal domain.

I‚Äôm using a slightly modified version of this micropub endpoint hosted on Netlify and I‚Äôm customizing a micropub client, it‚Äôs fully functional at the moment, but I‚Äôm still trying to figure out how to get it to store sessions longer (or indefinitely), it deletes them automatically after x time. Self-hosting a social reader like Together or Monocle sounds like the next reasonable step but I love yarr! too much to give up on it, so I finally put everything on a subdomain and this is how I‚Äôm posting and reading on the Internet these days:

I know there‚Äôs a lot to improve in this setup, and who knows, maybe some day, I can build implementations of IndieAuth, Webmentions, etc‚Ä¶ or build something as cool as Tanzawa or Eagle, but as of right now, this is something I‚Äôm kind of proud of and felt like that was worth sharing here.
content.text:
Two months ago I started implementing IndieWeb principles on my website. I use started because it has been a long process of tinkering with different tools and learning to use technologies I never expected to be using.
Naturally, the progress has been slow as I‚Äôm often running into problems beyond my skillset. However, by reaching out to other community members I‚Äôve been able to slowly setup things kind of the way I want. Because it‚Äôs true that on the IndieWeb everyone assumes you‚Äôre a developer, but most people are nice enough to open source their code and even go the extra mile helping with one‚Äôs particular use cases.
This website‚Äôs original goal was for me to have an online presence that was fully controlled by me, but thanks to the IndieWeb it‚Äôs turning into my single Internet channel. And how can it not progress in that direction when there‚Äôs many inspiring websites on the IndieWebring alone?
What started as moving my content back to Jekyll from Tumblr, resulted in personal website that implemented microformats, used a Heroku-hosted micropub endpoint and relied on Quill to post updates. Right now everything I need to post or read online is hosted on my personal domain.
I‚Äôm using a slightly modified version of this micropub endpoint hosted on Netlify and I‚Äôm customizing a micropub client, it‚Äôs fully functional at the moment, but I‚Äôm still trying to figure out how to get it to store sessions longer (or indefinitely), it deletes them automatically after x time. Self-hosting a social reader like Together or Monocle sounds like the next reasonable step but I love yarr! too much to give up on it, so I finally put everything on a subdomain and this is how I‚Äôm posting and reading on the Internet these days:




    
    
    
    


I know there‚Äôs a lot to improve in this setup, and who knows, maybe some day, I can build implementations of IndieAuth, Webmentions, etc‚Ä¶ or build something as cool as Tanzawa or Eagle, but as of right now, this is something I‚Äôm kind of proud of and felt like that was worth sharing here.

Hi, I‚Äôm Chuck Grimmett.

Check out my blog, see what I‚Äôm reading, dig around in my digital garden, learn a bit more about me, or search for something.

How to determine if a site uses Cloudflare cache with curl

Some WordPress Core Contributor stats

If a Visitor is There to See: WP-Cron and the Clock of the Long Now

Building a swing set with A-frame brackets

all posts‚Ä¶

I build boats with my friend Jon at the Hudson Boat Company. I‚Äôve built three kayaks and two Adirondack guide boats.

I do a lot of other woodworking besides boat building, too. My next projects: Making wooden toys for my son, turning bowls on the lathe, and making stick chairs.

I‚Äôm exploring and creating code-based art. It is a recent interest and I‚Äôm still trying to find my style.

I‚Äôve been into photography since 2006. You can see some of my work in the Photography category, on Flickr, and in the WordPress.org Photo Directory.

IndieWeb Stuff

My representative h-card that I still need to style:

Chuck Grimmett

I‚Äôm on the WordPress.com Special Projects Team at Automattic. When I‚Äôm not online, I prefer to be hiking, reading, or woodworking.

name: Send a Friend a Webmention Day

content.html:
30 July, 2023

Send a Friend a Webmention Day

Webmentions

By Pablo Morales
info iconIn reply to Send a Friend a Webmention Day on IndieWeb Events

It's been a great year so far! Lot's of good things have happened. I've overcame a few things. I started my blog again. The little things add up. One of the major events was becoming part of the IndieWeb Community. It's been a great community that is welcoming. I have learned so much from the people in the community and at Homebrew Website Club. Every single one of them has been pretty amazing.

Since it's Send a Friend a Webmention Day, I want to send a webmention to a few people.

Angelo Gladding

You were the first person I interacted with at Homebrew Website Club. He gave me the run down and help me connect the pieces based on the information I knew already. Thanks for being so rad! Your bot trained with your voice is pretty tight alongside your mediasoup-based setup.

Tracy Durnell I really enjoy your style of writing! I have been looking for better ways to express myself through writing and to find my style of blogging, it's inspiring and I enjoy your content. I've been wanting to make the Apple crumb pie. I'm excited to try it soon! If you need some more information on Oaxacan cuisine, I'm your guy!

James G Everything you do is super cool especially the programming language you created! You'll have to try some Coffee (and hot chocolate) from Oaxaca. I really enjoyed this month's IndieWeb Carnival topic.

Benji I love what you are doing with your site. I love the minimalist approach. The Sparkles is so rad! It works beautifully with one of my sites.

gRegor Love I hope you picked the blue shirt! I still haven't seen the movie? Yay or nay? Thank you for pointing me in the right directions when it comes to marking up content in a different language. More of content in different languages coming soon.

Alex Sirac Ton site, R√©ussir Mes √âtudes est super cool et informatif! J'aime le blog de ton site web principal. You've inspired me to write in French again!

Jo dead.garden Since I love languages, I started looking into toki pona. Thank you so much for sharing this.

Anthony Ciccarello Thank you for helping me out microformats and "likes" and getting that squared away. Every time I see you post about your puppy I immediately want to pet but we haven't broken the virtual-physical barrier yet to pet dogs yet. Any ideas?

Also as a Midwesterner, I saw you have a recipe for Puppy Chow. I will probably be making a batch once I get home.

Colin Walker I'm really digging your site. I also stumbled on your Music and I'm really digging it! I'd love to talk about your music since I am teaching a sound engineering class. I've been making progress on the e-book as well.

Syndicated on IndieWeb News

Syndicated on IndieWeb News

name: The Chicken-Egg Problem of Movie Microformats

content.html:
In the recent IndieWeb event (I think it was the Black Friday Create Day, but I am not 100% sure if it was), there was a discussion about the microformats. We then continued this conversation somehow in the next London Homebrew club.

The conversation started with, may have been Benji's idea of having sort of like a planet or aggregator for movies. Basically, to see what the people around are watching and how much they are liking the thing, they are watching.

The conversation went into two direction. One was how to use the algorithm (they wanted to use artificial intelligence), that would be able to discover the watch posts. Though, in the later session, we did also touch upon the problems of post types - what type of post is, when somebody goes to the cinema to watch a movie and writes a review of the venue. A watch post? A checkin? A review?

But I would like to address the second point. The reason the conversation went in the direction of automatic detection of the post type was, that most people are not marking up their watch movies. And that this is always a chicken and egg problem - nobody markup their sites, so it is not possible to build anything for the lack of data and this again does not give the the users reasons to markup their data.

And I am not saying that this is not a problem. I think Jeremy mentioned it related to recipes once.

So in order to try and see how much of the problem is, I went to the Microformats wiki and the IndieWeb wiki and tried to see, if I could mark them in this way. I started to search for movie and film and went from then.

Now, I don't make watch posts. But I do keep track of all the movies and series that I have watched.

And I do mention movies in the blog posts related to non-movie related topics. Here is one on creativity inspired by director interview, a fanfiction story, where I got the idea while watching the movie and another one about how all types of knowledge are useful.

None of which could be classified into a different watch posts. I don't really have different post types precisely because I think they would box my writing to much. I already box myself in my writing too much by the simple reason of how having enough time to write every idea that I have an my interests.

But checking the wikies, the only thing that I could find about it is the property u-watch-of? And it seems much more related to the watching of the internet videos than anything?

I watched about 5-times more movies in the cinema then any other media combined (including internet, streaming and DVDs). So even if I link to them, it is not really to the movie itself, but to the information about the movie? Still, it was not hard to find the couple of recent examples in the posts and add another class to it.

It also does not really indicate, that this is a movie, right? I guess this could also be use to indicate watching a Youtube videos like this one or this one?

So is this the end? Is there something else, that I should be marking? Because it does not seems like it would be that useful. On the other hand, I did not really find any information about what to do more of?

So I think it is a bit premature to say that nobody would be willing to markup, if there is not even easy way to figure out how to markup.

And yes, I work for the software company. I understand that to the many people that program, it is a lot more fun to figure out programmatic way to figure things out instead of writing an accessible documentation. :)

On the other side... I might be biased, since my job at work is writing and maintaining integration. I am sure that even with people not marking anything, it would be possible to build a proof of concepts. Scraping is not that scary, and in these cases, you probably don't even need to deal with the methods, that would actively try to block you.

I am sure enough people post this data (wiki have some examples, and there are probably other on the internet) for at least showing some possible prototype. And maybe some accessible information about how to add ourselves.

I think this community have enough joiners to have at least something.

Sure, this is all under the assumption, that this is something we do want. If nobody is willing to work on any of the sides of this problem, then maybe this is not a problem that we need solving. There is no point in maintaining code, that nobody is that interested in using.

name: What Movies do IndieWeb People Watch? Project Proof of Concept

content.html:
Motivation for the Project

Recently Benji had brought up the idea of the movie aggregator. We had conversation about it on a couple of Homebrew website clubs, there was a session about it on San Diego IndieWeb Camp and we had a conversation about it through our site (starting with this and currently, probably finished, here).

If I understood his idea, his idea was more a feed of movies that people were watching. And the review aggregator. Now, I do post the list of movies I watched, but I don't do separate posts and I don't do reviews or rating. After this project, I could be convinced otherwise on the reviews, but still don't want to put the numerical rating on it.

But I found the idea of finding the common interest interesting. Could this be used to see, if some people are watching common movies? What I would be even more interested is to see, if there are some common books we are reading.

But unlike with books, where I do read books outside of Goodreads, Open Library or Google Books, and even with the ISBN numbers, there does not seems to be a good way to connect different editions and different translations and so on. Open Library is having this data for the books in their database. It seems that this problem would require some more work.

On the other hand, I have yet to watch the movie, that was not in the IMDB (Internet Movie Database). So as long as I could sort of map it to there, I would have a way to connect movies for different members.

The First Proof of Concept

So I have created the first proof of concept to see, if anybody is even interested in this.

It had the three parts to it.

The first part is the network representation of the common movies. It does require JavaScript, so for the people that have it blocked, here is the current picture.

It simply shows either just the common movies or all the movies, and it is possible to filter by IMDB genre. Something that looks pretty. It was also the idea I started with, which is why it stayed the part of it.

The second one is some general statistics. It starts with the leader board of the common movies. I was a bit surprised, that it was Enola Holmes who was the most watched movie. Not the best movie I watched this year, but also not the worst movie I watched this year.

After that, there are some general statistics of the movie based on the IMDB metadata. I found two things interesting: the year distribution of the movies (the oldest movie watched was from 1900) and the country distribution (we hit all the continents sans Antarctica).

Though it also made me realise all the problems I have with the IMDB metadata.

The third one is the posters page. It just lists the posters of the watched movies, with the list of people that watched it underneath.

It also allows filtering by the IMDB metadata. Currently one can only filter by one thing at the time. Just some playing.

If you want to see the representation of my problem with the IMDB metadata, then just try to filter the movies by country Japan. It includes a lot of movies, that I would not put there, as I would not consider them Japanese movies. But it is easily accessible, so it is there.

Technical Background

It is a statically generated site. In the background it is this jupyter notebook. I have used OMDb API in the background to get movies metadata and to try to recognise the movies in the posts, that do not have the IMDB URLs in their watched movies list.

To update the data, I need to run this code locally. So in updates on the sporadic timetable.

Thanks to the Early Participants

I would here like to thank Benji, Jeremy, Mark and Tracy to give me permission to scrape their data and use it in this project.

Volunteer for Participation

If you want to have your data included in this project, please contact me. I prefer to not use the data from somebody else without their permission. Lets us try to be more ethical then the current tech industry. :)

Also, at least two people pointed me to the better source of movies on their site. Without it, I would have listed a smaller amount of movies for them.

Future Ideas

Surprisingly, it was the poster page, that had so far provided the most utility to me. It reminded me of the movies that I wanted to watch, but did not yet. And I could check, if they have the DVDs for them in the library.

In the last year pop up about libraries on the websites, there was the idea of the book club. If we could find the common books that multiple people wanted to read, we could have an IndieWeb-like book club. Or something in this direction? And if I could parse the want-to-read book in the same way, it would be possible to see is there are any common books. Or if done with the already read books, to be able to have book discussions?

And I guess the same could be done with movies? I am in one of the group, that does online groups movie watching, so if somebody would be interested in that, this could also be possible? In this case, I would also need to be parsing people's want-to-watch movies list. Do somebody even post this on their websites?

Any Feedback?

But honestly, I would be happy for some feedback. Is this something, that is interesting? Could you see a use case for something like that? Or any feedback you might have.

You can email me, post on your website and send me a webmention or a pingback, find me on discord or just find me on any IndieWeb event I RVSPs to.

Also posted on IndieWeb News.

Now, I do post the list of movies I watched, but I don't do separate posts and I don't do reviews or rating. After this project, I could be convinced otherwise on the reviews, but still don't want to put the numerical rating on it. 
But I found the idea of finding the common interest interesting. Could this be used to see, if some people are watching common movies? What I would be even more interested is to see, if there are some common books we are reading. 
But unlike with books, where I do read books outside of Goodreads, Open Library or Google Books, and even with the ISBN numbers, there does not seems to be a good way to connect different editions and different translations and so on. Open Library is having this data for the books in their database. It seems that this problem would require some more work.
On the other hand, I have yet to watch the movie, that was not in the IMDB (Internet Movie Database). So as long as I could sort of map it to there, I would have a way to connect movies for different members.
The First Proof of Concept
So I have created the first proof of concept to see, if anybody is even interested in this. 
It had the three parts to it. 
The first part is the network representation of the common movies. It does require JavaScript, so for the people that have it blocked, here is the current picture.

It simply shows either just the common movies or all the movies, and it is possible to filter by IMDB genre. Something that looks pretty. It was also the idea I started with, which is why it stayed the part of it.
The second one is some general statistics. It starts with the leader board of the common movies. I was a bit surprised, that it was Enola Holmes who was the most watched movie. Not the best movie I watched this year, but also not the worst movie I watched this year.
After that, there are some general statistics of the movie based on the IMDB metadata. I found two things interesting: the year distribution of the movies (the oldest movie watched was from 1900) and the country distribution (we hit all the continents sans Antarctica). 
Though it also made me realise all the problems I have with the IMDB metadata.
The third one is the posters page. It just lists the posters of the watched movies, with the list of people that watched it underneath. 
It also allows filtering by the IMDB metadata. Currently one can only filter by one thing at the time. Just some playing.
If you want to see the representation of my problem with the IMDB metadata, then just try to filter the movies by country Japan. It includes a lot of movies, that I would not put there, as I would not consider them Japanese movies. But it is easily accessible, so it is there.
Technical Background
It is a statically generated site. In the background it is this jupyter notebook. I have used OMDb API in the background to get movies metadata and to try to recognise the movies in the posts, that do not have the IMDB URLs in their watched movies list. 
To update the data, I need to run this code locally. So in updates on the sporadic timetable. 
Thanks to the Early Participants
I would here like to thank Benji, Jeremy, Mark and Tracy to give me permission to scrape their data and use it in this project. 
Volunteer for Participation
If you want to have your data included in this project, please contact me. I prefer to not use the data from somebody else without their permission. Lets us try to be more ethical then the current tech industry. :)
Also, at least two people pointed me to the better source of movies on their site. Without it, I would have listed a smaller amount of movies for them.
Future Ideas
Surprisingly, it was the poster page, that had so far provided the most utility to me. It reminded me of the movies that I wanted to watch, but did not yet. And I could check, if they have the DVDs for them in the library. 
In the last year pop up about libraries on the websites, there was the idea of the book club. If we could find the common books that multiple people wanted to read, we could have an IndieWeb-like book club. Or something in this direction? And if I could parse the want-to-read book in the same way, it would be possible to see is there are any common books. Or if done with the already read books, to be able to have book discussions?
And I guess the same could be done with movies? I am in one of the group, that does online groups movie watching, so if somebody would be interested in that, this could also be possible? In this case, I would also need to be parsing people's want-to-watch movies list. Do somebody even post this on their websites?
Any Feedback?
But honestly, I would be happy for some feedback. Is this something, that is interesting? Could you see a use case for something like that? Or any feedback you might have.
You can email me, post on your website and send me a webmention or a pingback, find me on discord or just find me on any IndieWeb event I RVSPs to. 
Also posted on IndieWeb News.

content.html:
Went to feed some Highland Cattle

Events I attended:

  • Homebrew Website Club Europe/London
  • Homebrew Website Club - Pacific

Learning

  • AI Course - Google
  • Cyber Security - Google
  • Learning New Features of GAM (Google Account Manager) to become a powerful Google Workspace Admin

Socializing

  • Showing my colleague's brother around Sacramento. We're hoping to
  • Had lunch with a colleague.
  • Reconnected with a childhood friend.

Exercise

  • Went on 3 runs this week. I started running in kilometers instead of miles.
  • Did plenty of cardio exercises beyond running.
  • Went on a hike in near Alta, CA
  • Visited a Pine Tree Fram (Christmas Farm)

Meals/Food

  • I ate a sandwich from Panera - Tuna (Work provided)
  • I ate a burger.
  • I had Chicken Tenders.
  • I made homemade flautas.
  • Ate a delicious vegan chocolate cookie from Sacramento Natural Food Co-op.

Me Time

  • I took myself on an artist date. I ordered a matcha latte with almond milk at Camelia Coffee Roasters .

Tech Stuff

  • I fixed the Docker Images to my website. Everything is 100% running via docker now.
  • Benji and Angelo helped me out reduce the number of bots and crawlers hitting my website. I've been checking my logs and it is now it is very minimal but I'm still tweaking as I go. Thanks dudes!
  • gRegor pointed out to me that my microformats on my blog were not set correctly. Luckily, we got it figured out ! Thanks gRegor!

Music I listened To

I build boats with my friend Jon at the Hudson Boat Company. I‚Äôve built three kayaks and two Adirondack guide boats.

I do a lot of other woodworking besides boat building, too. My next projects: Making wooden toys for my son, turning bowls on the lathe, and making stick chairs.

I‚Äôm exploring and creating code-based art. It is a recent interest and I‚Äôm still trying to find my style.

I‚Äôve been into photography since 2006. You can see some of my work in the Photography category, on Flickr, and in the WordPress.org Photo Directory.

content.html:
Benji has an article on Fun with Image Maps and SVGs that‚Äôs a bit technical but also really fun. At one time I could rattle off the code for an image map pretty easily. And a few months ago I put up a page in the lab about server-side image maps (best left in 1997). Lately I‚Äôve been writing more code that‚Äôs spacial in nature‚ÄìCSS gradients and backgrounds are 2-D canvases where we place items in position using numbers. He discovered the fact that image maps scale based on pixel width, and so they don‚Äôt quite work right when we have the capability to set images to scale based on device and screen width. His solution is novel and involves SVGs, which is terrific.

In talking about it today on the IndieWeb Homebrew Website Club I decided to play with another approach, using percentage based absolutely positioned elements. I‚Äôm not totally happy with the result. It feels brittle. And if the image changes to be a different aspect ratio or the styling on the page changes the container it‚Äôs possible what works now won‚Äôt work in the future.

Benji‚Äôs SVG approach feels a bit more robust. Something about having the code for the map refer to the image, all in the same markup, and without relying on CSS, makes me think that as long as you have that pair the code will work when the thing you made gets moved, copied, and repurposed.

Fun stuff!
content.text:
Benji has an article on Fun with Image Maps and SVGs that‚Äôs a bit technical but also really fun. At one time I could rattle off the code for an image map pretty easily. And a few months ago I put up a page in the lab about server-side image maps (best left in 1997). Lately I‚Äôve been writing more code that‚Äôs spacial in nature‚ÄìCSS gradients and backgrounds are 2-D canvases where we place items in position using numbers. He discovered the fact that image maps scale based on pixel width, and so they don‚Äôt quite work right when we have the capability to set images to scale based on device and screen width. His solution is novel and involves SVGs, which is terrific.
In talking about it today on the IndieWeb Homebrew Website Club I decided to play with another approach, using percentage based absolutely positioned elements. I‚Äôm not totally happy with the result. It feels brittle. And if the image changes to be a different aspect ratio or the styling on the page changes the container it‚Äôs possible what works now won‚Äôt work in the future.

Benji‚Äôs SVG approach feels a bit more robust. Something about having the code for the map refer to the image, all in the same markup, and without relying on CSS, makes me think that as long as you have that pair the code will work when the thing you made gets moved, copied, and repurposed.
Fun stuff!

content.html:
(Not to be confused with Rubenerd and Clara's PenguinCoffee.)

I have been experimenting with using my personal knowledge graph to write poetry this week. Using KGL, my knowledge graph query language, I can look up a concept, or a concept connected to another concept. I explored various concepts I have talked about on my blog, then started to write a poem based exclusively on words I have written.

Using KGL, I can see relationships in new ways. Whereas when I write a blog post, the context that I take in is limited to what is on my mind and in my notes at the time, KGL lets me put those concepts in context; to connect concepts from one blog post into a broader graph that I can explore. There is one big limitation, though: my knowledge graph contains my existing notes. Thus, using knowledge graphs for ideas is about synthesis, not explicitly new idea generation.

At Homebrew Website Club this evening, Benji used the "shortest path" feature in KGL. This finds the shortest possible path between two nodes in the graph. Benji searched for the shortest conceptual path between "penguin" and "coffee", to which the system responded:


penguin
around, waddles
someone, may browse
tea, smelled
i, drink
coffee, like

That is another way of saying:

  • Penguins waddle around
  • Someone waddles around
  • Someone may browse around, and smell
  • Tea smells, and I drink tea
  • Like how I drink coffee

KGL creates bi-directional links between concepts, so sometimes the order is reversed. I can manually decipher the order since I am working with my text, but for a new source of information you would have uni-directional links. Uni-directional links would result in fewer connections, though. There would be less to explore. Hence I like to make all concept links bi-directional.

Here, I have woven connections between different concepts in a novel way. Up until now, I had not thought about penguins and coffee in this way. Benji prompted the exploration. KGL helped me put it in context of both general ideas -- "someone", "may browse" -- and concepts that I write about a lot ("tea", "drink").

Here is the shortest path between "me" and "taylor swift":


me
features, do not resonate with
a library, provides
i, made
of monsters and men, listen to
some artists, include
taylor swift, include

Here is one for the shortest path between "community" and "music":


community
body of resources, have
have
i, do
music, made

Uni-directional links would result in fewer connections, though. There would be less to explore. Hence I like to make all concept links bi-directional.

content.html: Just a friendly hello to some pals from Homebrew Website Club! Joe, Sara, Tracy, James, Benji, Angelo, David, Pablo, gRegor, Jo‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sure there are several people I‚Äôm missing.
content.text: Just a friendly hello to some pals from Homebrew Website Club! Joe, Sara, Tracy, James, Benji, Angelo, David, Pablo, gRegor, Jo‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm sure there are several people I‚Äôm missing.

content.html:
One of the best things about Homebrew Website Club is meeting new nerds. Sometimes it feels like each new club meeting brings in someone new!

River, as far as I can tell you don't have a site yet, but good luck getting started in th IndieWeb. We're all here to help.

Joe, I'm happy to sign your guestbook, and I'm looking forward to exploring your site (specially your comics.) You've got a long history to spelunk! (UPDATE: having checked out some of the comics, I'm just jealous that someone can manage to be an artist, a writer, a surfer, and a programmer all at once!)

Rosalina, I love your wacky purple website and carefree attitude to posting. Open mind -> retrieve thought -> make post: I dig it. Keep it up.

It was good to reconnect with the regulars, too. Angelo and I have a long history, of course, but Dave, Tracy, and Benji were welcome sights as well. Shout out to Benji for making the best MicroPub client I've ever seen! I'm going to be using it for the foreseeable future.

(UPDATE: having checked out some of the comics, I'm just jealous that someone can manage to be an artist, a writer, a surfer, and a programmer all at once!)
Rosalina, I love your wacky purple website and carefree attitude to posting. Open mind -> retrieve thought -> make post: I dig it. Keep it up.
It was good to reconnect with the regulars, too. Angelo and I have a long history, of course, but Dave, Tracy, and Benji were welcome sights as well. Shout out to Benji for making the best MicroPub client I've ever seen! I'm going to be using it for the foreseeable future.
